Title: The Silence of States in International Law

This project seeks to investigate the silence of States in international law, a critical yet understudied topic. The proposed research aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the legal implications of State silence, inaction, and their binding nature in international law. The study will develop a taxonomy of State silences, analyzing their legal effects and critically assessing whether a change in the law is necessary.

Through a mixed-methods approach, combining analysis of State practice in six official UN languages, international jurisprudence, and literature, as well as empirical analysis of government officials' and international judges' reasoning, this project will fill a significant knowledge gap. The research will focus on three key areas: the binding nature of State silence, State inaction and responsibility, and State inaction in international dispute settlement proceedings.

The significance of this project lies in its potential to inform and shape the behavior of States, international courts and tribunals, domestic courts, and individuals. By clarifying the legal implications of State silence, this research will contribute to a more effective and efficient international legal system. The project's findings will be disseminated through academic publications, workshops, and policy briefs, ensuring that the research has a lasting impact on international law and practice. Ultimately, this project will provide a foundation for States, international courts, and other stakeholders to navigate the complexities of State silence and inaction in international law.
